abstract: foreign ownership climbs in montreal , new data shows .
article: live montreal more streams montreal has seen a `` statistically significant '' increase in the number of non-resident buyers this year , a new report says , suggesting investors may be shifting their focus to quebec 's largest city after foreign buyer crackdowns in toronto and vancouver . the non-resident share climbed in montreal from 1.1 per cent in 2016 to 1.7 per cent in 2017 , according to new statistics provided by the canada mortgage housing corporation and statistics canada . downtown and nuns ' island reported the largest increase in the montreal area , up from 4.3 per cent in 2016 to 7.6 per cent this year .

bob dugan , cmhc 's chief economist , said the recent lack of growth in the rate in toronto and vancouver , combined with the increases in montreal , `` indicate the possibility of a shift from these centres after the introduction of foreign buyers taxes in ontario and british columbia . '' `` other factors attracting demand to montreal include lower housing prices and a relatively strong economy , '' he said . non-residents of canada own less than 5 % of housing in toronto , vancouver the percentage of non-resident owned property remains relatively low in montreal , however , compared to toronto and vancouver .

time for a tax ? chinese buyers account for the bulk of montreal 's recent increase in foreign buyers . twenty-one per cent were from china in 2017 , compared to 10 per cent in 2016 . ontario introduced a tax on foreign buyers earlier this year , while british columbia did the same in 2016 . reasons why the canadian property market refuses to fall : don pittis montreal mayor val√©rie plante wants the power to be able to introduce a foreign buyers ' tax . but she would require the approval of the quebec government , which has so far deemed such a tax unnecessary .
